title: Riot, please stop allowing 2 people to control the time of the other 3 at a whim.
body: 3/2 surrender votes should be surrenders.  The majority of the team said yes, and your newfound focus on punishing leavers means those two people are now trapping the other 3 in a game that the majority of the team does not want to be in anymore.  Your system is causing more toxicity and unneeded stress when 3 players get trapped because a duo doesn't care what anyone wants.

You can't win every game, if you think you can I dunno what else to tell ya.

Also, you CAN win every game. You are probably not going to, but every game is possible to win until the nexus says defeat. I just played a 5s ranked match. We were all high silver-low gold players against 3 Plats, a Diamond, and a high Gold (rito matchmaking OP) and were down 2 inhibs and about 15 kills + 2 drags and a nexus tower. They pushed into our base, I ulted as Fiddles, taking out their ADC that overextended, and my team followed up beautifully for the ACE and win.

You CAN win every game, it is just whether you are able to get it done or not.

My personal stance is that it should require a unanimous decision, but be available from the 10 minute mark.

I'd rather 'punish' 3 people by making them play the game(which is not a punishment since that's what you queued up to do in the first place) than ACTUALLY punish 2 people with a loss because 3 of their players didn't recognize that the game was far from over.

When the enemy mid, jungler, adc, and top laner all can kill 4 out of the 5 people on your team in roughly 1 second, but they won't actually take the base because they're having fun.  That's when it's a punishment to be forced to abide by a duo who's raging at the team and wants to troll them, or one guy who has a good score convincing someone that there's a reason to continue only to finally lose to the enemy team dancing and laughing around the nexus 50 minutes in.

Games get to that point once in a million games. Literally. There's no point in instituting something that applies to every game for the ultimate rare extreme.

As to your kat point... there are other aspects you can practice. Maintaining defensive vision so she can't jump on you, hold turrets against fed teams, etc.

Those extremes simply aren't common enough to justify a change in rules. Most games that fail to a 3/2 surrender are 'oh we can't win a teamfight 'cause they're stronger than us' not 'everyone on their team one-shots us'. Games rarely reach that point. So can we please talk about the NORMAL cases, not the absurd extremes?
Literally?  Literally once in a million games?  I've seen this more times than I can count and I've played far, far less than a million games.

> [{quoted}](name=InsaneSamurai,realm=NA,application-id=cIfEodbz,discussion-id=Nd5wTlJ9,comment-id=000a000000000001,timestamp=2015-01-05T22:56:52.032+0000)

I've literally NEVER seen it. So ya, I'd say it's a 'literally once in a million' thing.  A case where the enemy team has a carry toplaner, hypercarry adc, assassin jungle, assassin mid, and they're ALL fed enough to do the 'sub-1 second kill' thing. That's CRAZY rare.

Seriously?  You have never been fighting a team with one tank and 4 fed damage dealers? Just about any fed (played)assassin kills a squishy in 2 hits, and those 2 hits aren't going to take much more than a second(if they even do).  If the jungler isn't tanky or has been getting counterjungled(which dominating teams tend to do), he's going to be pretty squishy as well.  A feeding top laner is squishy pretty much no matter what champ he's playing.   Things like a fed Nidalee kill any squishy that gets hit by any cc because her spears take 70-80% of their life.  Akali.  etc. etc.

When it's just one guy killing your team that fast, there's often still a decent chance.  When it's 3 or 4 of them, you really shouldn't be wasting more time just letting them stat pad or whatever on you since they could obviously win at any point and are simply choosing not to.

It takes an absurd level of feeding for anyone short of a hypercarry or an assassin to kill in ONE SECOND. Even more adcs outside of hypercarries of graves can't kill in one second. It takes at least 3-4 hits(which takes usually at least 2 seconds) for even a fed normal adc to kill you.

And for a toplaner or a jungler who isn't an assassin to do it in one... that requires crazy levels of strength. You're talking a full build toplaner vs a 1-item squishy to get 'one second'. Like 5-6 levels difference.

That doesn't happen often.

I never said disable surrenders, I said it should require a unanimous decision. In order to take a game from 'low chance to win' to 'no chance to win' - which is what surrendering does - it should take the entire team making the decision.

I also never said that games where you get slaughtered are one in a million, I specifically said that games where 4 out of 5 players on the other team can kill you in ~1 second are one in a million.

However, if they're 'just waiting in the jungle for you' then they're not making money, so you should gradually narrow the gap by farming lanes if they do it for long enough. And if they're farming the jungle, then they can't all be watching all entrances at the same time and you should be able to get vision of a few spots to try to make something happen when they're not all there. Take a bit back here and there. It's not LIKELY, but it's not impossible. If a team's goal isn't to win the game, then you can win it by out-thinking them no matter how far ahead they are. How far they are ahead just determines how badly you have to out-think them and how long it will take.

I use to think that too but after awhile my opinion changed. There are dozens of times where i wanted to surrender but 2 people didn't and it drove me crazy. There are also dozens of time where i wanted to surrender, but 2 people didn't and then they led us to victory.  

Here is the other part of it, the enemy team may not want to stop playing. If they are having fun and the 2 people on your team are having fun then that's 7 people having fun and 3 not, majority of the people are having a good time. Maybe there should me a mercy vote with a 3/2 split (or a 2/2 in the case of an afk i guess) where the other team gets to decide whether to give mercy or keep playing. Personally though i think there should be at least 2-3 failed votes before the other team gets to mercy vote.

None of this changes the fact that the *majority* of your team wants to call it a game.  Building a system where two people can cage the other 3 in a game as long as they can drag it on(stay and put up with it or face Riot punishments), is not good for anyone.  People will argue, people will try to convince each other to surrender/not surrender and start arguments off that.  The game is over, people are just fighting and clicking no to spite each other at that point and it needs to stop.

When the game is obviously over yea those 2 are caging the other 3 and in this case i feel the other team should get to decide whether to give mercy or not. When the game isnt decided yet but you guys just want to quit instead of trying and i think we can win if we just started to cooperate better then im not caging you, you are caging me. 3 to 2 isnt a good advantage anyways, specially when the game can be won or lost by one person. Besides like i said its possible that its 7 to 3 in wanting to keep playing, so why should 3 people decide the game for the other 7? Your own logic used against you except with a better majority.  

I will agree that the Surrender system has its flaws but not for the same reasons.

Many of the times that this becomes a serious problem, it is because the enemy team is just milking the game and not finishing.  In these cases they would never allow a surrender, because their goal is to stay fed and winning as long as possible at the expense of the other team.

The other team is not included because it's a surrender vote.  The deciding factors are the people on the team that is losing, determining if they have lost enough to not drag on the game.  In a world where most people didn't care more about themselves than anyone else, sure, allow the enemy team into the vote.   In this world, 9 out of 10 times they're not going to help you out just to be honorable.  They're going to do the same exact thing, trap you in the game cause they have 20 kills and they wanna keep instakilling people who have no chance at all of putting up a fight.  If you want to play this game to get fed and just faceroll the enemy team over and over again without taking objectives, you're not doing it right, and Riot's systems should not cater to that in any way at all.

Agreed there are a lot of poor sports out there but i feel 4/1 is the most fair for deciding whether to surrender or not. In your example it is a pain in the ass to deal with that, but its just something you need to accept as part of the community. Even though they are being poor winners their opinion still matters and they are having fun, unfortunately at the expense of others. If you want to have a fair system you need to take both sides into account, thats just how 'fair' works, and a 4/1 vote is the most fair with only 1 team voting.

4 to 1 is not even remotely fair.  All the one guy needs is a friend or someone he can easily sway, and he traps the rest of the game.

It's rarely even worth trying at that point anyway.  The vote comes up, and 2 say no when the other 3 believe there is absolutely no reason to continue.  So you stay and argue about surrendering and whose fault it is and who should have picked what champ for a few minutes, the vote comes back, you click no, and proceed to continue arguing.  How is this better than ending the game and playing a new one with a new team?

Well actually 4 to 1 is very fair, if 4 people want to surrender and 1 doesn't then it should be a surrender.  

It seems me and you have different experiences which is effecting our opinions on this subject so there is no point in continuing, neither of us are going to change. You have bad experiences with surrender-system and i actually tend to win most of the game that we fail to surrender.
